title: Snap and YouTube: The Rise of Subscription Strength
description: Exploring how subscription services are boosting revenue for Snap and YouTube, and what it means for the future of digital media.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'Life is Artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're diving into the fascinating world of digital media companies, specifically focusing on two big players: Snap and YouTube. Both companies have just reported their quarterly earnings, and there's one key takeaway that's got everyone talking: subscription services are now driving growth like never before.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Our source today is The Information, which published an insightful article titled 'Snap, YouTube Highlight Strength in Subscriptions'. If you'd like to read more in detail, be sure to check out the link in our show notes.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Let's start with Snap. The company’s subscription service, Snapchat+, has now reached 12 million subscribers. That's up from 11 million last quarter, and more than double compared to the same time last year. Snapchat+ costs just $3.99 a month, and although it doesn't represent a huge chunk of Snap's overall revenue, it's definitely playing a key role in boosting growth.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Advertising is still Snap’s bread and butter, with ad revenue rising by 10% to $1.25 billion this quarter. However, non-ad revenue, most of which comes from Snapchat+, helped Snap reach an overall revenue increase of 15%, hitting $1.37 billion. It's interesting to see how these supplementary revenues are making a real difference for Snap.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Now, Snapchat+ hasn’t been without its challenges. One of the features it introduced allowed users to see how their friends ranked them, which sparked some controversy. Snap later turned this feature off by default, citing concerns over user wellbeing. Despite that, the growth of Snapchat+ seems pretty promising.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: On the user side, Snap still has its challenges, especially in North America. The number of people using Snapchat in the U.S. has stagnated at around 100 million. While global user growth is on the rise, this flatlining in its largest market has been a concern for Snap. But Snap isn’t just standing still; the company is working to attract more creators to its platform, and it's making a major push to grow its augmented reality efforts. In fact, the number of creators posting content increased by 50% compared to last year.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: To make things even more exciting, Snap is also testing a redesigned version of the app, aiming to simplify the user experience. About 10 million users are currently testing it, and CEO Evan Spiegel believes this could be key in attracting more users and boosting advertising performance.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Snap stock actually jumped 10% in after-hours trading, helped by a $500 million share buyback plan. It seems investors are pretty happy with what they’re seeing from Snap, despite the challenges.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Moving on to YouTube, things are looking very bright there as well. Google reported that YouTube’s revenue from ads and subscriptions over the past four quarters crossed $50 billion for the first time, which means YouTube is now bigger than Netflix in terms of revenue. For this quarter alone, YouTube's ad revenue increased by 12%, reaching $8.9 billion.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: It's fascinating to see YouTube becoming such a giant. They're concentrating on making YouTube more watchable on big screens, and they're also giving creators more tools to make content feel more like traditional TV, with options to organize videos into seasons. This really plays into the trend of blurring the lines between online content and traditional television.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And let's not forget YouTube Shorts, which is their answer to TikTok. Apparently, 70% of channels uploading to YouTube each month are now uploading Shorts, and they’re also working on ways to make watching these Shorts less awkward on TV screens. It shows YouTube’s dedication to making sure all its formats work, no matter where you are or what device you’re using.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So what does this all mean for digital media? It’s clear that the rise of subscription services is providing an important buffer against the fluctuations in ad spending. Both Snap and YouTube have shown that having diversified revenue streams is key to continued growth, especially in an environment where advertising revenue alone can be volatile.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: For Snap, Snapchat+ is helping to bolster the numbers even as competition heats up, particularly from TikTok. For YouTube, subscriptions and ad innovations are driving growth, and they’re adapting their formats for different screens to stay ahead of viewer habits.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That's it for today’s episode of 'Life is Artificial'. If you want to read the full article from The Information, the link is in the show notes. Thanks for tuning in, and as always, stay curious! Until next time.
